dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Tachyzoite phosphoproteome from purified parasite or infected host cell (RH)
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Protein samples were prepared from infected host cells or from purified T gondii RH strain tachyzoites. Phosphorylated and non-phosphorylated peptides were separated by SCX chromotography, enriched by IMAC chromotography, and analyzed by LC-MS/MS. To discover the peptide composition of samples, mass spec data was searched against TgME49 and TgGT1 peptide databases.
dataSourceAttribution.description:
Sample collection and mass-spectrometry were performed by Moritz Treeck and John Sanders of the Boothroyd and Elias labs at Stanford University, respectively. See further explanation in Treeck et. al., 2011, Cell Host & Microbe, in press.

Intracellular RH tachyzoite samples:
Tachyzoites (RH strain) were used to infect HFF (human foreskin fibroblasts) for 28h. Extracellular parasites were washed off and the parasite-infected host cells lysed and the entire sample used for phosphopeptide enrichment and mass-spectrometry.

Purified RH tachyzoite samples:
Purified tachyzoite samples (RH strain) were prepared by infection of HFFs with RH parasites for 28h. To remove host cell material and parasite proteins present within the host cell or parasitophorous vacuole, the infected cultures were syringe-lysed and the released parasites were then purified by gel chromatography as described in Dunn et. al., 2008 (Infection & Immunity). All parasite samples were lysed in 8m urea lysis buffer, followed by trypsin digestion, strong-cation-exchange (SCX) chromatography and IMAC phosphopeptide enrichment (Villen and Gygi, 2008). Samples enriched for phosphopeptides and the flow through (containing predominantly non-phosphorylated peptides) were analyzed in duplicate via LC-MS/MS and the resulting spectra were searched against appropriate parasite protein sequence databases concatenated with reversed decoy versions of these sequences using the SEQUEST algorithm (Eng et al., 1994). Phosphorylation sites were localized using the AScore algorithm (Beausoleil et al., 2006) and the dataset was filtered using the target-decoy strategy (Elias and Gygi 2007, 2010) for peptide and phosphorylation site-FDRs <1% and a protein FDR <3%. This bulk FDR prediction estimates that fewer than 1% of the identifications are incorrect. Given that a phosphopeptide was correctly identified, its phosphorylation sites are necessarily present, but the siteâ€™s localization to a specific amino acid can be ambiguous. As a result, the Ascore algorithm was used to help localize phosphorylation sites to a specific residue. This algorithm calculates the relative likelihood that the indicated amino acid is phosphorylated versus the next-most likely residue on the peptide. An Ascore >19 indicates a >99% likelihood that the indicated phosphorylation site is correctly assigned; an Ascore >13-represents a 95% likelihood; and an Ascore >10 corresponds with a >90% likelihood. As a rule of thumb, a phosphorylation site with many spectral counts, indicating many observations, tend to be more abundant than those with fewer spectral counts. While it is true that most incorrect identifications have few spectral counts, it is not necessarily the case that phosphorylation sites with few spectral counts are incorrect. Further scores to evaluate each individual site and peptide can be found in the supplementary data Table S1 and S2 in Treeck et. al., 2011, Cell Host & Microbe, in press.

Proteomics data provided by Silvia Moreno's lab from the University of Georgia, Athens, GA. Two data sets (samples A and G) were graciously provided pre-publication. Samples were prepared from RH parasites by Silvia Moreno's laboratory at the University of Georgia, Athens, GA and analyzed by James Thompson and John Yates, III at The Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla, CA.
This data was graciously provided to ToxoDB pre-publication by Silvia Moreno (smoreno@cb.uga.edu).

Toxoplasma gondii FOU strain genome sequence data were produced by JCVI as part of the Toxoplasma white paper.


Data Usage Policy

NIAID is committed to rapid, pre-publication release of genomic data and recognizes that clinical data and other metadata associated with the genomic data are valuable research resources. For these reasons, NIAID endorses rapid release of all genome data sets. To comply with this policy, the whole genome sequences of T. gondii strains are being submitted to NCBI and included here in ToxoDB prior to complete annotation. Once annotation is complete and submitted to GenBank, the entries for these new genomes will be updated in ToxoDB. The users of any released data are expected to act responsibly to recognize the scientific contribution of the data producers by following normal standards of scientific etiquette and fair use of unpublished data. In particular, we ask that users not perform genome wide comparisons/analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes of the data sets deposited here without first contacting the organizing committee. We welcome your input in this process, but would also like to coordinate community efforts to with the goal of producing a collective report for publication. If you have an idea for analyses that would be useful, please contact one of us to coordinate your contribution to the community effort.


Brian Brunk, Hernan Lorenzi, David Roos & David Sibley, on behalf of the Toxoplasma genome consortium, representing the white paper committee, the JCVI genome sequencing center, and the ToxoDB team.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Toxoplasma gondii GCN5-A Array from Sullivan.
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Differential experssion of TgGCN5-A null mutant under Alkaline growth conditions compared to wild type.
dataSourceAttribution.description:
Differential experssion of TgGCN5-A null mutant under Alkaline growth conditions compared to wild type.

Disruption of the gene encoding for TgGCN5-A in type I RH strain did not produce a severe phenotype under normal culture conditions, but here we show that the TgGCN5-A null mutant is deficient in responding to alkaline pH, a common stress used to induce bradyzoite differentiation in vitro. We performed a genome- wide analysis of the Toxoplasma transcriptional response to alkaline pH stress, finding that parasites deleted for TgGCN5-A fail to up-regulate 74% of the stress response genes that are induced 2-fold or more in wild-type. Using chromatin immunoprecipitation, we verify an enrichment of TgGCN5-A at the upstream regions of genes activated by alkaline pH exposure. The TgGCN5-A knockout is also incapable of up-regulating key marker genes expressed during development of the latent cyst form, and is impaired in its ability to recover from alkaline stress. Complementation of the TgGCN5-A knockout restores the expression of these stress-induced genes and reverses the stress recovery defect. Click here for link to GEO

Authors: Arunasalam Naguleswaran, Eliana V. Elias, Jeanette McClintick, Howard J. Edenberg, William J. Sullivan Jr

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Expression profiling of the 3 archetypal T. gondii lineages
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Expression profiling of two strains from each of the 3 archetypal T. gondii lineages. This data was graciously provided to ToxoDB pre-publication by Paul Davis and David Roos.
dataSourceAttribution.description:
Expression profiling of two strains from each of the 3 archetypal T. gondii lineages was generated as per the following experiment:
At least three T25 flasks containing confluent monolayers of human foreskin fibroblasts grown in D10 media were infected with approximately 1x107 T. gondii tachyzoite parasites per strain. After 6hrs, the media was replaced with fresh D10. Approximately 40hr post-infection (and prior to observable host cell lysis), media was removed and flasks were washed once with 1x cold PBS. Cell monolayers were scraped in 5ml 1x cold PBS, and centrifuged for 12min, 750g at 4C. Supernatant was removed, and RNA was isolated from the cell pellets using Qiagen RNEasy kit according to manufacturer's instructions.
Strains utilized:
Type I:   RH and GT1
Type II:  Pru and ME49
Type III: CTG and VEG
This data was graciously provided to ToxoDB pre-publication by Paul Davis and David Roos.

dataSourceAttribution.summary: Mature "day 10" Toxoplasma gondii oocysts of the Type II M4 strain were fractionated into walls (bleach treated, and untreated) and sporocysts/sporozoites. Protein preparations were analyzed by 1DE, LC-MS/MS.
dataSourceAttribution.description:
Heather M. Fritz*, Paul W. Bowyer*, Matthew Bogyo, Patricia A. Conrad, John C. Boothroyd *these authors contributed equally to this work

Mature "day 10" Toxoplasma gondii oocysts of the Type II M4 strain were used for proteomic characterization of the wall and sporocyst/sporozoite fractions of the oocyst by mass spectrometry. Two experiments using 100 million oocysts each were performed. For each experiment oocysts were fractionated into wall and sporocyst/sporozoite components. In the second experiment, the 100 million oocysts were first divided into bleach-treated and not-treated fractions. Bleach treatment was used to remove the outer layer of the bilayered oocyst wall before fractionation. Therefore, comparison of the bleach-treated to not-treated walls allowed us to interrogate the inner versus outer wall location of identified proteins in the wall fraction. Data from the bleach-treated and not-treated sporocyst fractions in experiment two were pooled, as bleach treatment of the intact oocysts should not affect the sporocysts within.

Peptide identifications for the following oocyst fractions are provided:

1. Oocyst walls (bleach-treated)
2. Oocyst walls (not-treated)
3. Sporocysts/Sporozoites

Sample preparation:

Oocyst harvest, bleach treatment and fractionation into walls and sporocysts/sporozoites Unsporulated oocysts were harvested from the feces of infected kittens and sporulated for 10 days. Sporulated oocysts were then purified using a CsCl gradient separation. Half of the oocysts in the second experiment were treated with bleach to remove the outer layer of the oocyst wall. For each sample, oocysts were separated into walls and sporocysts using an iodixanol (Optiprep, SIGMA) gradient separation.

Protein Preparation and Mass Spectrometry (MS)

Oocyst fractions were separated by 1-D SDS-PAGE on a 7 cm long gel. The entire length of each sample lane was cut into 14, 0.5 cm, slices. Gel slices were subjected to in-gel digestion with trypsin before analysis on an LTQ ion trap mass spectrometer (ThermoFisher).

LC-MS/MS

Peptides were separated on a Basic Picofrit C18 capillary column coupled to an Eksigent nanoLC-2Dï£ª pump before analysis on an LTQ ion trap. Peptides were eluted with an acetonitrile gradient from 0 to 60% in a 0.1% solution of formic acid over 2hr. Dynamic exclusion was enabled for 180 sec.

Data Analysis

Searches were performed against a custom concatenated target-decoy database containing the annotated proteins based on the T. gondii ME49 release 5 sequences. Peptides in the +1, +2 and +3 charge-states were required to have minimum XCorr values of 1.8, 2.5 and 3.5, respectively. The minimum requirement for deltaCN was 0.08. Both tryptic and semi-tryptic peptides are shown.

dataSourceAttribution.summary: Total protein from T gondii (RH strain) tachyzoites (harvested 3-4 days post-infection) was analyzed by 1DE, LC-MS/MS and MudPIT analysis. Purified tachyzoites were either solubilized directly in SDS sample buffer or prepared as Tris-soluble and Tris insoluble fractions prior to 1DE, LC-MS/MS. MudPit analysis was performed on Tris-soluble and Tris-insoluble fractions.

MudPIT Soluble Fraction

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Toxoplasma gondii cell-Infect Array from Carruthers.
dataSourceAttribution.description:
Here we show that host cell transmission of the obligate intracellular parasite Toxoplasma gondii is closely tied to specific cell cycle distributions, with egress and reinvasion occurring most proficiently by parasites in the G1 phase. We also reveal that Toxoplasma undergoes marked changes in mRNA expression when transitioning from the extracellular environment to its intracellular niche. These mRNA level changes reflect a modal switch from expression of proteins involved in invasion, motility and signal transduction in extracellular parasites to expression of metabolic and DNA replication proteins in intracellular parasites. Three sample types were harvested: extracellular, intracellular 0hr, intracellular 2hr. 2 replicates each. Expression for >80% of the regulated genes exhibits a steady downregulation during invasion. Click here for link to GEO

Authors: Rajshekhar Y. Gaji, Michael S. Behnke, Margaret M. Lehmann, Michael W. White, Vern B. Carruthers

Data Usage Policy

NIAID is committed to rapid, pre-publication release of genomic data and recognizes that clinical data and other metadata associated with the genomic data are valuable research resources. For these reasons, NIAID endorses rapid release of all genome data sets. To comply with this policy, the whole genome sequences of T. gondii strains are being submitted to NCBI and included here in ToxoDB prior to complete annotation. Once annotation is complete and submitted to GenBank, the entries for these new genomes will be updated in ToxoDB. The users of any released data are expected to act responsibly to recognize the scientific contribution of the data producers by following normal standards of scientific etiquette and fair use of unpublished data. In particular, we ask that users not perform genome wide comparisons/analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes of the data sets deposited here without first contacting the organizing committee. We welcome your input in this process, but would also like to coordinate community efforts to with the goal of producing a collective report for publication. If you have an idea for analyses that would be useful, please contact one of us to coordinate your contribution to the community effort.


Brian Brunk, Hernan Lorenzi, David Roos & David Sibley, on behalf of the Toxoplasma genome consortium, representing the white paper committee, the JCVI genome sequencing center, and the ToxoDB team.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: T. gondii mutants and wild-type during bradyzoite differentiation in vitro
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Analysis of seven novel T. gondii insertional mutants that do not undergo normal differentiation to bradyzoites.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Toxoplasma gondii pathogenesis includes the invasion of host cells by extracellular parasites, replication of intracellular tachyzoites, and differentiation to a latent bradyzoite stage. We present the analysis of seven novel T. gondii insertional mutants that do not undergo normal differentiation to bradyzoites. Microarray quantification of the variation in genome-wide RNA levels for each parasite line and times after induction allowed us to describe states in the normal differentiation process, to analyze mutant lines in the context of these states, and to identify genes that may have roles in initiating the transition from tachyzoite to bradyzoite. Gene expression patterns in wild-type parasites undergoing differentiation suggest a novel extracellular state within the tachyzoite stage. All mutant lines exhibit aberrant regulation of bradyzoite gene expression and notably some of the mutant lines appear to exhibit high proportions of the intracellular tachyzoite state regardless of whether they are intracellular or extracellular. In addition to the genes identified by the insertional mutagenesis screen, mixture model analysis allowed us to identify a small number of genes, in mutants, for which expression patterns could not be accounted for using the three parasite states--genes that may play a mechanistic role in switching from the tachyzoite to bradyzoite stage.

Adam James Reid, Damer Blake, Thomas Dan Otto, Alejandro Sanchez, Mandy Sanders, Yealing Tay, Paul Dear, Kiew-Lian Wan, Matthew Berriman, Arnab Pain, Fiona Tomley. Sequencing and annotation of the Eimeria tenella genome.


Funding: BBSRC, Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute


The data were produced by the Parasite Genomics group at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute to the standard of an Improved Draft. The Parasite Genomics group and collaborators plan on publishing the completed and annotated draft sequence in a peer-reviewed journal as soon as possible. Permission of the Principal Investigator (Matthew Berriman,mb4@sanger.ac.uk) should be obtained before publishing chromosome- or genome- scale analyses of the sequences or annotations.

Identification Toxoplasma gondii centromeres was performed by ChIP-chip using antibodies to Centromeric Histone 3 (CenH3-HA) colocalized with antibodies to H3K9me2.
For further information please contacts Kami Kim (kkim@aecom.yu.edu) or Boris Striepen (striepen@cb.uga.edu).
Toxoplasma isolates and sequences obtained from David Sibley (Contact: L. David Sibley sibley@borcim.wustl.edu)..

Sequence from cosmid ends mapped against T. gondii ME49, VEG and GT1 scaffolds.
End-sequence data from cosmid clones were provided by Ian Paulsen at TIGR. Sequencing was done using T3 and T7 primers represented as TH and TV, respectively, in the sequence IDs.
Cosmids with the TOX designation originated from Boris Striepen's laboratory, while those that start with PSB are from David Sibley's group. A detailed description of cosmid libararies from the Sibley lab is available here.

contact.name: CJ Tonkin
contact.institution: Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research

dataSourceAttribution.description: Protein samples were prepared from T. gondii RH strain tachyzoites that were stimulated with the calcium-mobilizing agent, ionomycin. Phosphopeptide-enriched and phosphopeptide-depleted fractions were separated by SCX chromotography, enriched by IMAC chromotography, and analyzed by MudPIT. Peptide discovery was performed on mass spec data using the SEQUEST or MASCOT algorithms as indicated. 305 non-redundant Toxoplasma phosphopeptides were identified.

dataSourceAttribution.summary: Enriched cytoskeletal and membrane fractions of T. gondii (STRAIN) were analyzed using three different proteomics techniques: 1DE, LC-MS/MS; 2DE, LC-MS/MS; or LC-MS/MS.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Enriched cytoskeletal and membrane fractions of T. gondii were separated by 1D-SDS-PAGE or 2D gel electrophoresis. The bands/spots were digested with trypsin. The resulting peptides analyzed by nanoLC-MS/MS on a ThermoFinnigan linear ion trap (LTQ) mass spectrometer. MASCOT was used to search the merged DTA mass spectrometry data file against the appropriate database to obtained unique peptide hits. In order to extend the dynamic range of the membrane fractions, high pH sodium carbonate was used to remove the peripheral membrane proteins. For a few experiments, the remaining cytosolic fractions were also analyzed. A total of 2604 proteins were identified by mass spectrometry in T. gondii to date. The 2604 predicted proteins cluster into 1534 groups of overlapping gene predictions that were identified by 14455 mass spectrometry peptide hits that gave an average 13.2% sequence coverage. Peptides from LC-MS/MS analysis by the Albert Einstein Biodefense Proteomics Research Center
Affymetrix probe data. Contact: David Roos or Amit Bahl abahl@mail.med.upenn.edu (University of Pennsylvania).

dataSourceAttribution.description: Cell cycle expression profiles from Behnke MS, Wootton JC, Lehmann M, Radke JB, Lucas O, Nawas J, Sibley DL, White MW.
SAGE tags for T. gondii provided on 2005-04-26, by Aaron Mackey and Michael Behnke, Michael White (Montana State University). Contact: Michael White uvsmw@montana.edu
The transcriptomes of in vitro tachyzoites 2 days postinfection, in vitro bradyzoites 4 days postinfection, and in vivo bradyzoites 21 days postinfection were interrogated by microarray
Affymetrix probe data. Contact: David Roos or Amit Bahl <tt>abahl@mail.med.upenn.edu</tt> (University of Pennsylvania).
T gondii (RH strain) tachyzoites were harvested soon after emerging from host cells. Conoid-enriched and conoid-depleted fractions were prepared from extracted parasite ghosts and analyzed by MudPIT.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Toxoplasma gondii RUB genome from JCVI
dataSourceAttribution.description:
Toxoplasma gondii RUB strain genome sequence data were produced by JCVI as part of the Toxoplasma white paper.


Data Usage Policy

NIAID is committed to rapid, pre-publication release of genomic data and recognizes that clinical data and other metadata associated with the genomic data are valuable research resources. For these reasons, NIAID endorses rapid release of all genome data sets. To comply with this policy, the whole genome sequences of T. gondii strains are being submitted to NCBI and included here in ToxoDB prior to complete annotation. Once annotation is complete and submitted to GenBank, the entries for these new genomes will be updated in ToxoDB. The users of any released data are expected to act responsibly to recognize the scientific contribution of the data producers by following normal standards of scientific etiquette and fair use of unpublished data. In particular, we ask that users not perform genome wide comparisons/analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes of the data sets deposited here without first contacting the organizing committee. We welcome your input in this process, but would also like to coordinate community efforts to with the goal of producing a collective report for publication. If you have an idea for analyses that would be useful, please contact one of us to coordinate your contribution to the community effort.


Brian Brunk, Hernan Lorenzi, David Roos & David Sibley, on behalf of the Toxoplasma genome consortium, representing the white paper committee, the JCVI genome sequencing center, and the ToxoDB team.

Scaffold genome sequence for T. gondii type I RH strain provided on 2006-09-25, by Matt Berriman (The Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute), Jim Ajioka (University of Cambridge). Contact: Matt Berriman mb4@sanger.ac.uk. (Chromosomes Ia and Ib only).

Using chromatin immunoprecipitation and microarray hybridization (Nimblegen arrays), we analyzed the patterns ofDNA-bound Histone H4(K5-K8-K12-K16) acetylation after 4 hours treatment of RH strain with DMSO (control) or 40 nM of FR235222 (named previously drug A) which is a Toxoplasma-specific HDAC inhibitor. ChIP-on-chip isolated DNA samples (input and immunopurified DNA) were arrayed on custom synthetic oligo arrays (387,000 features per array, 46-50 mer oligos, 2 arrays for the whole genome; Nimblegen). Peak calls were made by the data provider.
Gaps within chromosomes represented as features.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: SNPs from alignments of GT1, VEG and RH
dataSourceAttribution.description: SNPs generated by alignment with nucmer of GT1, VEG and RH resequencing to reference. Contact: David Roos or Amit Bahl abahl@mail.med.upenn.edu (University of Pennsylvania).

ChIP-on-Chip identification of chromosome-wide binding sites of Toxoplasma TBP1, TBP2, RNA polymerase (Rpb9 subunit) and the lysine methyltransferase TgSET8 (Sautel et al. 2007). These data were graciously provided to ToxoDB pre-publication. Contact Mohamed-Ali Hakimi, for further information.

Gregarina niphandrodes genome sequence data were produced by JCVI as part of the Toxoplasma white paper.


Data Usage Policy

NIAID is committed to rapid, pre-publication release of genomic data and recognizes that clinical data and other metadata associated with the genomic data are valuable research resources. For these reasons, NIAID endorses rapid release of all genome data sets. To comply with this policy, the whole genome sequences of T. gondii strains are being submitted to NCBI and included here in ToxoDB prior to complete annotation. Once annotation is complete and submitted to GenBank, the entries for these new genomes will be updated in ToxoDB. The users of any released data are expected to act responsibly to recognize the scientific contribution of the data producers by following normal standards of scientific etiquette and fair use of unpublished data. In particular, we ask that users not perform genome wide comparisons/analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes of the data sets deposited here without first contacting the organizing committee. We welcome your input in this process, but would also like to coordinate community efforts to with the goal of producing a collective report for publication. If you have an idea for analyses that would be useful, please contact one of us to coordinate your contribution to the community effort.


Brian Brunk, Hernan Lorenzi, David Roos & David Sibley, on behalf of the Toxoplasma genome consortium, representing the white paper committee, the JCVI genome sequencing center, and the ToxoDB team.

dataSourceAttribution.description:
Toxoplasma gondii MAS strain genome sequence data were produced by JCVI as part of the Toxoplasma white paper.


Data Usage Policy

NIAID is committed to rapid, pre-publication release of genomic data and recognizes that clinical data and other metadata associated with the genomic data are valuable research resources. For these reasons, NIAID endorses rapid release of all genome data sets. To comply with this policy, the whole genome sequences of T. gondii strains are being submitted to NCBI and included here in ToxoDB prior to complete annotation. Once annotation is complete and submitted to GenBank, the entries for these new genomes will be updated in ToxoDB. The users of any released data are expected to act responsibly to recognize the scientific contribution of the data producers by following normal standards of scientific etiquette and fair use of unpublished data. In particular, we ask that users not perform genome wide comparisons/analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes of the data sets deposited here without first contacting the organizing committee. dataSourceAttribution.displayName: T. gondii VEG protein GO Associations
dataSourceAttribution.description: T. gondii VEG Gene Ontology associations produced by Lis Caler's group at the J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI).

dataSourceAttribution.summary: The excreted/secreted antigen fraction was prepared from freshly egressed T. gondii strain 2F tachyzoites.Protein preparations were analyzed by 2DE-MS or by MudPIT analysis.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Two-dimensional electrophoresis/mass spectrometry and liquid chromatography/electrospray ionization-tandem mass spectrometry (MudPIT, shotgun proteomics) were utilized to analyze freely released proteins from T. gondii RH strain tachyzoites (RH clone 2F used in this study is a lacZ-expressing clone).

Using chromatin immunoprecipitation and microarray hybridization (Nimblegen arrays), we analyzed the patterns ofDNA-bound Histone H4(K5-K8-K12-K16) acetylation after 4 hours treatment of RH strain with DMSO (control) or 40 nM of FR235222 (named previously drug A) which is a Toxoplasma-specific HDAC inhibitor. ChIP-on-chip isolated DNA samples (input and immunopurified DNA) were arrayed on custom synthetic oligo arrays (387,000 features per array, 46-50 mer oligos, 2 arrays for the whole genome; Nimblegen). Peak calls were made by the data provider. Data provided by Mohamed-Ali Hakimi, Institut Jean Roget.
Affymetrix probe data. Contact: David Roos or Amit Bahl <tt>abahl@mail.med.upenn.edu</tt> (University of Pennsylvania).

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: T. gondii M4 Fritz/Buchholz Array Profiles
dataSourceAttribution.description:
Transcriptome analysis of oocyst,tachyzoite and bradyzoite development in the type II strain M4.

There were three primary objectives to the overall experiment.

     I. Describe the transcriptome of the oocyst through its development beginning with the freshly excreted, unsporulated oocyst at "Day 0" to a fully sporulated and mature oocyst at "Day 10" and including a mid-sporulation time-point at "Day 4".
     II. Compare the transcriptomes of in vitro (4 and 8 days post infection (dpi)) vs. in vivo (21 dpi) derived bradyzoites.
     III. Compare expression data from three life stages (oocyst, bradyzoite and tachyzoite) from the same parasite isolate, M4. This isolate has been characterized as a Type II strain.

The RNA was derived from parasites donated by the Moredun Research Intstitute, Edinburgh, Scotland, UK and belong to the same original isolate (T. gondii M4: J. Gutierrez et al. Veterinary Parasitology 172 (2010) 8-15.)

More specifically, RNA samples were obtained from:

     1. Oocysts harvested from kitten feces and purified for RNA extraction at Day 0, (not sporulated), Day 4 post-induction of sporulation (mid-sporulation) and Day 10 post-induction of sporulation. Oocysts were collected and combined from two kittens that were infected with the same starting material (mouse brains containing bradyzoite cysts). Duplicate samples were obtained from feces collected and purified on separate days.
     2. Bradyzoite cysts harvested from the brains of mice that were infected with oocysts (obtained from the oocysts harvested from kittens as described for the oocyst RNA). Mice were treated with 0.44 ug/ml sulfadiazine in their water days 11-21 pi to enable a chronic infection state. Mice were sacrificed on day 21 for cyst purification.
     3. In vitro 4 and 8 dpi bradyzoite and 2 dpi tachyzoite samples are from separately infected cultures of human foreskin fibroblasts (HFF) (replicate flasks for each condition and time-point were infected on the same day). Samples were harvested independently and kept separate for all the subsequent processing and labeling steps. Bradyzoite differentiation was induced by growth under low serum (1%) high pH (8.0) conditions without supplemented CO2 as described (Fux, B. et. al. Infect Immun 75:2580-90, 2007).

Authors: Heather Fritz*, Kerry R. Buchholz*, Patricia Conrad, and John C. Boothoryd. (* these authors contributed equally.)

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: HTS sequence reads from T. gondii RH provided by M-J. Gubbels
dataSourceAttribution.description: 100 bp paired end sequencing reads from T. gondii RH strain were generated on the Illumina platform and by Marc-Jan Gubbels. Reads were aligned to both the ME49 and GT1 genomes using BWA. SNPs were called using VarScan.
Affymetrix probe data. Contact: David Roos or Amit Bahl <tt>abahl@mail.med.upenn.edu</tt> (University of Pennsylvania).
